content.description: On the second tier above the creek. So far only route but there is room for quite a few more, all harder. Climb the steep face past on important jug that's a little loose. Plan to glue it at some point but haven't been back in a while.

This is a hoot. Being a fun girdle traverse, this is excellent practice for the aspiring aid climber or an endurance challenge for the visiting boulderer. The climber passes many of the bolts on the other routes and essentially traverses the crag left to right. At times during the traverse, the climber may find one's self less than 3 feet off the ground!! This boulder traverse will most likely be freed soon. It is a pretty lengthy band of rock so the traverse gives you distance. First climbed on a snowy wintery day.
content.protection: QDs, a variety of hooks. Some pitons and bolts were left fixed, but a few beaks might be helpful
content.location: Laminar Flow is a girdle traverse of The Freezer. This is the first sizeable chunk of limestone that one encounters hiking up Freeze Creek from Pioneer Fork Road.

climbs.name: Freezing Fingers
climbs.fa: James Garrett, February 2004 FFA: Steve Edwards

content.description: This is the bolted line on the left side up a overhanging short face of the Freezer Crag. The second climb from the left and just to the right of the shallow corner. Drilled ground up. These are fun routes if they are in your backyard and you really don't want to drive somewhere to go climbing! The rock is still somewhat chossy so be forewarned!
content.protection: QDs. Glue In bomber bolts at the top for rappel or TR
content.location: Freezer Buttress is up Freeze Creek about 15 minutes up the Freeze Creek trail head on Pioneer Fork Road

climbs.name: Donuts Direct
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Franziska Garrett, 28 April 2020

content.protection: Well protected with 5 bolts, some glue-ins including on the two bolt anchor. Belay bolt at waist level.
content.location: Far left of the Freezer Buttress. Left of a faint dihedral left of an overhanging part of the wall.

content.description: Another addition to the venerable Freezer Buttress. This little climb actually has a few cool moves. Maybe that is really subjective though! Destined for not alot of other visitors, and probably won't clean up until the next millenium. You gotta love this place for other reasons than the rock!
content.protection: 5 bolts to same anchors as for Freezing Fingers.
content.location: Follow directions to Freezer Buttress which is the first crag up Freeze Creek.

content.description: Crux is getting off the ground. This is also on The Freezer. This is a hard little route, too! If you can get off the ground on this one, you can do the whole route. Best TRed for the moment, I would presume.
content.protection: QDs. 4 bolts for protection. Two Bolt Belay
content.location: Just to the right of Freezing Fingers.

climbs.name: Coyote On The Move
climbs.fa: James Garrett and Franziska Garrett, Winter 2004

content.description: Crux is down low. This is the far right, possibly shorter route that also offers a moderate alternative to the others. 4 bolts protect this short pitch.
content.protection: QDs to a two-bolt belay on top of this Limestone Little Crag
